newsitem.title: USA: Procter & Gamble files to broaden Asacol use.
newsitem.headline: Procter & Gamble files to broaden Asacol use.

text.p: Procter & Gamble Co said on Tuesday it filed an application with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to broaden the use of its Asacol tablets, and said it received two new U.S. patents for the drug.
Asacol Delayed-Release Tablets are used to treat mildly to moderately active ulcerative colitis, a chronic large intestine disorder affecting about 250,000 Americans a year.
The company said in a statement it filed a supplemental application for clearance to use the drug as maintenance therapy for ulcerative colitis.
If cleared, Procter said the drug could be used maintain remission of the disease in patients.
The FDA accepted this application for review, the company said.
The company also said the U.S. Patent office granted it two new patents covering the colon-targeted release properties of Asacol. The patents expire in 2013, it said.
Procter said adverse effects associated with Asacol ere mild and reversible. They include headaches, abdominal pain and gas, the company said.
